Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Correlates and Consequences of Risks from Airborne Toxics: A Dynamic Spatial Analysis

In the past two decades there has been increasing interest in understanding the extent and causes of racial and socioeconomic inequalities in the distribution of environmental burdens. This interest has been spurred by a visible and growing environmental justice movement, by public concerns about the health and other quality of life consequences of pollution, and by increasing government attention to these issues. This study analyzes the geographic distribution of airborne industrial toxic pollution in the United States over time to address several questions: (i) Have rates of reduction in air pollution risk over time differed between low-income and predominantly minority communities and other communities? (ii) How does the interaction between income and race/ethnicity as correlates of exposure to point-source air toxics vary across regions and across industrial sectors? (iii) How does individual mobility affect racial and socioeconomic disparities in cumulative exposure: who moves, who stays, and do those who move relocate to more or less polluted localities?

The study uses a unique dataset from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Risk Screening Environmental Indicators Geographic Microdata (RSEI-GM). The data offer a fine-grained picture of exposure to industrial toxic air releases identified by chemical and source facility for the entire U.S. for the years 1988-2007. The study will merge the RSEI-GM data with tract-level socioeconomic and demographic data from the 1990 and 2000 Censuses and the 2004-2009 pooled American Community Survey as well as individual-level data from the 1986-2001 Americans Changing Lives Survey.

Broader Impacts

This project will establish an infrastructure for the development, maintenance, and sharing of the complex RSEI-GM pollution-exposure database, spatially merging it with social, economic, demographic, and health data, and training graduate students in the management and use of the data. The project will make analytic results available in useful format to public and private decision-makers, including communities, regulators, shareholders, and other stakeholders.

This project examines the changing geographic distribution of airborne industrial toxic pollution in the United States in relation to changing social, economic, and demographic characteristics of affected communities and individuals. The study uses a unique new dataset from the Environmental Protection Agency that provides highly detailed geographic data on exposure to industrial toxic air releases identified by chemical and source facility. This data is called the Risk Screening Environmental Indicators (RSEI) and it is built on air modeling of data reported in the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI); because we are using the finest geographic unit possible, we refer to the data as the RSEI-GM with the GM referring to geographic microdata. The goals of the project include both furthering the state of environmental justice research by examining how patterns of environmental inequality have changed since the mid-1990s, and developing a very complex dataset for broader use by researchers in the field of environmental inequality as well as building the field of environmental justice studies by introducing the questions and methods to new researchers.

Our empirical analysis examines changes in patterns of environmental inequality in the U.S. since the mid-1990s – a period over which toxic releases were on the decline generally. Our preliminary findings point to contrasting national and regional trends. Nationally, all people have benefited from the decline in ambient toxic concentrations from RSEI facilities (including because of the closure of RSEI facilities) that occurred between 1995 and 2010, and communities of color as a whole in the U.S. have disproportionately benefited. While this would seem to be good news, given past patterns of disparity, one worrisome trend is that the fewer higher risk facility that have emerged over this time period are disproportionately in communities of color.

More importantly, this improvement in the national pattern is not reflected when one looks within states and/or metropolitan areas and takes into consideration that improvement can only happen in areas where there are relatively high levels of toxic concentration to begin with. Rather than being driven by intraregional (or within region) improvement, the improved national pattern (and regional patterns, where evident) seems to be largely driven by a combination of two explanations: (1) Given that low-income people and people of color are far more likely to live in areas of high toxic concentration in the first place, they are more likely to be the beneficiaries of reduced toxic concentration. (2) Reduced toxic concentrations in states and regions with larger shares of people of color can improve the national pattern of disproportionate exposure without improving the pattern within those states and regions.

Once we control for base period levels of toxic concentration and regional fixed effects, we find that on average areas with a larger share of the population that was white in the base period tended to see larger declines in toxic concentration over the subsequent decade. This is an important point to consider for policies around the regulation of pollution, which are made and implemented at the state and regional levels. While improving patterns of environmental justice within regions is generally an objective of such regulators, the evidence does not suggest that such improvements are being made.
